en.introduction: Different return metrics tell different stories. Absolute return shows your total profit, while XIRR accounts for timing of investments. If you invested ₹50,000, added ₹30,000 six months later, and the portfolio grew to ₹100,000, your absolute return is impressive but XIRR might be different. This calculator shows why understanding both matters.

inputsExplained: XIRR (Extended Internal Rate of Return): Annualized return accounting for timing of each transaction
Absolute Return: Total percentage gain regardless of investment timeline
Time-Weighted Return: How performance varies when investments happen at different times
Total Profit: Absolute rupee gain from your investment
en.formulaExplanation: Absolute Return = [(Final Value - Total Invested) / Total Invested] × 100%. This is simple total profit percentage. XIRR solves NPV = 0 = Σ [Cash Flow / (1 + XIRR)^(days/365)], where each transaction is weighted by duration invested. Example: If you invest ₹100 in year 1 and it becomes ₹110 in year 2, absolute return is 10%. But if you invest ₹100 in year 1, then invest another ₹100 in year 2 (year 2 investment only grows from 100 to 110), XIRR will be lower because half your money only earned 10% while half earned 0% so far.

seoContent.introduction: Is your 50% absolute return better than 20% XIRR? Confusing? This calculator clarifies: Absolute return ignores timing (simple math), XIRR accounts for when you invested (realistic). Learn which metric matters for your funds and investments.
benefits: Compare absolute return and XIRR side-by-side
Understand why XIRR is more accurate measure
See impact of investment timing on returns
howToUse: Calculator shows both absolute return and XIRR
Understand which is most relevant for your situation
seoContent.formulaExplanation: Absolute Return = (Final Value - Initial Value) / Initial Value × 100. XIRR uses IRR formula accounting for timing. Example: Invested ₹10 lakh over 2 years (₹5 lakh each year), current value ₹15 lakh. Absolute = 50%, but XIRR ≈32% (because half was invested second year). XIRR is more realistic metric.
examples: Invested ₹10 lakh Nov 2022, current ₹15 lakh = 50% absolute, but actual XIRR depends on timing
SIP investors: ₹1 lakh total invested over years, value ₹2 lakh = 100% absolute return if all invested upfront, but XIRR lower due to staggered investment
Portfolio ₹25 lakh invested, now ₹35 lakh = 40% absolute, XIRR may be 15-20% depending on investment spread
seoContent.whoShouldUse: Mutual fund investors comparing performance metrics, SIP investors tracking true returns, portfolio managers evaluating fund performance, individuals comparing multiple funds with different investment timelines, anyone confused about return calculations.
seoContent.importantNotes: For SIP/multiple investments: XIRR is correct metric. For single lumpsum: both give same result. Absolute return can be misleading (high absolute % doesn't mean good annualized return). Always use XIRR for performance comparisons across different time periods.

faqs.question: Why is XIRR better than absolute return?
faqs.answer: Absolute return ignores timing. Someone investing ₹10 lakh 5 years ago vs ₹10 lakh today shouldn't have same return metric. XIRR accounts for this, showing true annualized performance.

faqs.question: If I see 60% absolute return, is it good?
faqs.answer: Depends on timeline. 60% over 1 year = excellent (60% XIRR). 60% over 10 years = poor (4.8% XIRR). Always ask: 'How many years?' Absolute return alone is misleading.

faqs.question: Can absolute return be higher than XIRR?
faqs.answer: For recent investments yes. If you invested ₹10 lakh 3 months ago and it's ₹11 lakh, absolute = 10%, but XIRR = ~40% annualized. XIRR extrapolates to annual rate.

faqs.question: Which metric should I use to compare funds?
faqs.answer: Always use XIRR/CAGR for same time period. Compare funds with same 3-year, 5-year, 10-year XIRR. Absolute return can't be compared across different time periods.

faqs.question: How did my 50% absolute return become 15% XIRR?
faqs.answer: Probably invested over longer period (5+ years) with multiple additions. Each addition compounds for different duration. XIRR accounts for this averaging effect.
